week1.practice1_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in waves and you haven’t yet seen baby hairs. With high stress, irregular periods, and ongoing thyroid/med changes, your body is stuck in “onset/peak” territory. The single domino that steadies this cycle is locking in sleep timing—because stable circadian rhythm flattens the stress-hormone swings that keep pushing hairs into telogen. 🌙

What to do

  • Pick one bedtime and wake time—keep both within a 30‑min window every day.
  • Get light to your eyes within 30 min of waking (natural light if possible).
  • Cut off caffeine after noon; avoid meals right before bed to aid deep sleep.
  • Make your sleep space dark, cool, and quiet for longer stretches of deep sleep.

Your recommended schedule

  • Bedtime: 10:45–11:15 pm (lights out by 11)
  • Wake: 7:00–7:30 am (anchor wake every day, even Sunday)
  • 8h sleep window supports recovery + growth signals

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set a nightly “wind‑down alarm” at 10:15 pm to step away from screens and journaling rumination.
  2. Keep caffeine cutoff at 12 pm; switch to water or herbal tea afterward.
  3. Eat dinner earlier (ideally 2h before bed) so digestion doesn’t delay repair cycles.
  4. On high‑stress days, add a simple 5‑minute breathing exercise before lights out to calm cortisol.
  5. Keep bedroom cool and dark; use blackout shade or eye mask if dawn light wakes you.

Why this works (for you)

  • Because your chronic thyroid/medication stress is ongoing, regular sleep cues lower night cortisol spikes that otherwise delay shedding stabilization.
  • Your shed waves fit with TE lag: illness (Feb) + meds (Mar–May) likely pushed hairs into telogen in summer. Consistency here shortens the lag window so regrowth can begin on time.
  • Irregular cycles + possible low iron = fragile hair substrate. Deep, stable sleep improves progesterone/thyroid tone, which protects follicles until nutrients catch up.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Staying up >90 min past your set bedtime regularly → pushes back your hormone rhythm. If this happens often, reset by anchoring wake time, not bedtime.
  • Green lights: By week 2, anxiety at night feels calmer; by week 3, sleep onset is faster; shedding feels steadier (less “wavey”).
  • Be patient with yourself—consistency, not perfection, moves you toward stabilization ❤️.
